P.title: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, South Korea is recognized as the leader in global digital governance based on the following criteria: 
- South Korea must have implemented comprehensive digital governance policies that are adopted and followed by at least 75% of its population, as verified by government reports and independent surveys. 
- South Korea must hold a prominent position in international digital governance forums, such as the OECD and G20, where it leads discussions and initiatives on digital policy, cybersecurity, and data privacy. 
- The country must be acknowledged in at least three reputable international reports or rankings (e.g., by the World Economic Forum, UN, or similar organizations) as the top nation in digital governance practices. 
- Significant collaborations or partnerships with at least three other countries in establishing global digital standards must be in place, with documented agreements and initiatives. 
In the absence of clear consensus, the question will resolve as No.

metadata.source_question: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?

Q.title: Will South Korea establish a comprehensive digital identity system by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the South Korean government has officially established a comprehensive digital identity system that allows citizens to securely verify their identity online across multiple platforms, including government services, financial institutions, and private sector services. The system must include features such as biometric verification, secure data storage, and user consent management. The establishment of the system must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The system must be fully operational and not in a pilot or trial phase.

metadata.source_question: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?

P_and_Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (1) By December 31, 2030, South Korea is recognized as the leader in global digital governance based on the following criteria:

- South Korea must hold a prominent position in international digital governance forums, such as the OECD and G20, where it leads discussions and initiatives on digital policy, cybersecurity, and data privacy. 
- The country must be acknowledged in at least three reputable international reports or rankings (e.g., by the World Economic Forum, UN, or similar organizations) as the top nation in digital governance practices. 
- Significant collaborations or partnerships with at least three other countries in establishing global digital standards must be in place, with documented agreements and initiatives. 
(2) By December 31, 2025, the South Korean government has officially established a comprehensive digital identity system that allows citizens to securely verify their identity online across multiple platforms, including government services, financial institutions, and private sector services. The system must include features such as biometric verification, secure data storage, and user consent management. The establishment of the system must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The system must be fully operational and not in a pilot or trial phase.

metadata.source_question: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?

Q.title: Will South Korea lead the development of international digital privacy standards by 2028?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, South Korea has been recognized as the leading nation in the development of international digital privacy standards by at least three major international organizations or forums focused on digital privacy, such as the International Organization for Standardization (ISO), the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF), or the Global Privacy Assembly. The recognition must be based on formal agreements, publications, or resolutions that establish South Korea's role as a primary contributor to these standards. Additionally, the standards must be adopted or endorsed by at least five countries, including South Korea, to qualify for this resolution. If South Korea is a significant contributor but not the recognized leader, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: Will South Korea's digital governance model be adopted by at least three other countries by 2032?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, at least three countries have officially adopted a digital governance model that is substantially similar to South Korea's current digital governance model as of 2023. The adoption must be confirmed through official government announcements or reputable news sources (such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, etc.). The model must include key elements such as e-government services, digital identity systems, and data privacy regulations that align with South Korea's framework. If a country adopts a modified version of the model, it will still count towards the resolution as long as the core principles remain intact. Countries that only implement pilot programs or temporary measures do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q.title: Will South Korea implement nationwide 5G infrastructure by 2024?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, South Korea has fully implemented nationwide 5G infrastructure that is operational and available to the general public in all major urban areas. The implementation must be confirmed by official government announcements or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). The infrastructure must support the standards set by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) for 5G networks, including peak data rates of at least 20 Gbps and latency of less than 1 millisecond. If there is partial implementation, the question will resolve as Yes only if the government has a clear plan for full nationwide coverage and timeline for completion.

Q.title: Will South Korea host a major international summit on digital governance by 2026?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, South Korea has officially hosted a major international summit focused on digital governance. The summit must involve participation from at least five countries and have a clear agenda addressing topics such as data privacy, cybersecurity, digital economy, and international regulations on digital technologies. The confirmation of the summit must be reported by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must include official government documentation or announcements. If the summit is postponed or canceled, the question will resolve as No.

P.title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially invited to join NATO and the invitation is accepted by the Ukrainian government. The invitation must be documented in an official NATO communiquÃ© or similar authoritative source. Additionally, the acceptance must be confirmed by a public statement from the President of Ukraine or the Ukrainian government. The resolution will also consider the status of Ukraine's membership in NATO if it has completed all necessary reforms and met the criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's Membership Action Plan. Any temporary or conditional invitations that do not lead to full membership by the specified date do not count towards a Yes resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

Q.title: Will Ukraine receive a Membership Action Plan from NATO before 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, NATO officially grants Ukraine a Membership Action Plan (MAP). The decision must be made during a NATO summit or through an official announcement from NATO's Secretary General or the North Atlantic Council. The Membership Action Plan must be recognized as a formal step towards NATO membership for Ukraine. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (such as BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the decision will suffice. Any informal discussions or intentions expressed by NATO officials do not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Ukraine join NATO before 2030 (2) Ukraine receive a Membership Action Plan from NATO before 2025?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially invited to join NATO and the invitation is accepted by the Ukrainian government, documented in an official NATO communiqué or similar authoritative source, with confirmation from the President of Ukraine or the Ukrainian government, and all necessary reforms have been completed; (2) Before January 1, 2025, NATO officially grants Ukraine a Membership Action Plan (MAP), confirmed by an official announcement from NATO's Secretary General or the North Atlantic Council, or by credible reports from at least three major news organizations. Any temporary or conditional invitations that do not lead to full membership by the specified date do not count towards a Yes resolution.

P.title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

Q.title: Will Ukraine achieve a membership action plan with NATO by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Ukraine has been officially granted a Membership Action Plan (MAP) by NATO. The resolution will be based on an official announcement from NATO confirming the MAP status for Ukraine. The MAP must include specific commitments and timelines for Ukraine's integration into NATO, as outlined in NATO's official documentation. If Ukraine is granted a MAP but it is limited to specific conditions or timelines that do not align with NATO's standard procedures, the question will resolve as No. Additionally, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the grant of the MAP will suffice in the absence of an official announcement.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Ukraine join NATO before 2030, and (2) Ukraine achieve a Membership Action Plan with NATO by 2025?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially invited to join NATO, and the invitation is accepted by the Ukrainian government, documented in an official NATO communiqué or similar authoritative source, and confirmed by a public statement from the President of Ukraine or the Ukrainian government. Additionally, Ukraine must have completed all necessary reforms and met the criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's Membership Action Plan. (2) By December 31, 2025, Ukraine has been officially granted a Membership Action Plan (MAP) by NATO, confirmed by an official announcement from NATO, including specific commitments and timelines for Ukraine's integration into NATO. If either of these conditions is not met, the question will resolve as No.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

Q.title: Will any NATO member state oppose Ukraine's membership before 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, any NATO member state officially declares its opposition to Ukraine's membership in NATO. This opposition must be made through a formal statement by a government official or through an official communication from the NATO organization. The statement must explicitly mention opposition to Ukraine's membership and cannot be vague or ambiguous. Statements made in informal settings, such as interviews or social media, do not count unless they are later confirmed through official channels. In case of multiple statements, the first official declaration of opposition will determine the resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Ukraine will join NATO before 2030, and (b) no NATO member state will oppose Ukraine's membership before 2030?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially invited to join NATO and the invitation is accepted by the Ukrainian government, and at the same time, no NATO member state officially declares its opposition to Ukraine's membership. The invitation to NATO must be documented in an official NATO communiqué or similar authoritative source, and the acceptance must be confirmed by a public statement from the President of Ukraine or the Ukrainian government. Additionally, the resolution will consider the status of Ukraine's membership in NATO if it has completed all necessary reforms and met the criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's Membership Action Plan. For the second part, this question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, no NATO member state makes a formal statement of opposition to Ukraine's membership. Any formal statement must explicitly mention opposition to Ukraine's membership and cannot be vague or ambiguous. Statements made in informal settings do not count unless confirmed through official channels.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

Q.title: Will Ukraine hold a national referendum on NATO membership before 2027?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2027, Ukraine officially holds a national referendum regarding its membership in NATO. The referendum must be recognized by the Ukrainian government and conducted under the oversight of international observers to ensure fairness and legitimacy. The results of the referendum must be made publicly available and reported by reputable news sources such as BBC, The Guardian, or Reuters. Any preliminary discussions or proposals for a referendum do not count; the actual voting event must occur.

P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if both conditions are met: (1) Before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially invited to join NATO, and the invitation is accepted by the Ukrainian government, with documentation in an official NATO communique or similar authoritative source, and acceptance confirmed by a public statement from the President of Ukraine or the Ukrainian government, considering Ukraine's completion of necessary reforms and meeting NATO's Membership Action Plan criteria. (2) Before January 1, 2027, Ukraine officially holds a national referendum regarding its NATO membership, recognized by the Ukrainian government, conducted under international oversight, with publicly available results reported by reputable news sources. Any preliminary discussions or proposals for a referendum or temporary invitations to NATO do not count towards a Yes resolution.

Q.title: Will Ukraine resolve its territorial disputes with Russia before joining NATO?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, Ukraine has officially resolved its territorial disputes with Russia through a binding agreement that is recognized by both parties and the international community. The resolution must involve clear terms regarding the status of the disputed territories and must be confirmed by a reputable international organization or a consensus of major news outlets (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). In the absence of such an agreement, any unilateral declarations or temporary ceasefires will not count towards the resolution of this question.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030? (2) Will Ukraine resolve its territorial disputes with Russia before joining NATO?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially invited to join NATO and the invitation is accepted by the Ukrainian government, as documented in an official NATO communiqué or similar authoritative source, and confirmed by a public statement from the President of Ukraine or the Ukrainian government, while also considering the status of Ukraine's membership in NATO if it has completed all necessary reforms and met the criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's Membership Action Plan. (2) Before January 1, 2025, Ukraine has officially resolved its territorial disputes with Russia through a binding agreement recognized by both parties and the international community, involving clear terms regarding the status of the disputed territories, and confirmed by a reputable international organization or a consensus of major news outlets.

P.title: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, credible evidence demonstrates that Microsoft's carbon negative pledge has led to a measurable reduction in global CO2 levels. The reduction must be at least 1% of global CO2 emissions compared to levels recorded in 2020, as reported by authoritative sources such as the Global Carbon Project or the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). The impact must be attributed directly to Microsoft's initiatives and not to other external factors or global events. The evidence must be supported by peer-reviewed research or official reports from reputable organizations (e.g., UN, World Resources Institute) that analyze the effectiveness of corporate carbon pledges on global emissions.

metadata.source_question: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?

Q.title: Will Microsoft's carbon negative initiatives lead to a measurable decrease in CO2 emissions in the tech sector by 2028?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, there is clear and measurable evidence that Microsoft’s carbon negative initiatives have resulted in a quantifiable decrease in CO2 emissions across the tech sector. The evidence must be based on credible reports from independent environmental organizations or peer-reviewed studies that demonstrate a reduction in CO2 emissions attributed to Microsoft's initiatives. The reduction must be statistically significant, defined as a decrease of at least 10% in CO2 emissions from the baseline year of 2020. The resolution will also consider the overall impact of Microsoft's initiatives on the tech sector, including partnerships and collaborations with other companies in the industry. Reports must be published in reputable outlets, such as the New York Times, BBC, or scientific journals that focus on environmental science.

metadata.source_question: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impacts global CO2 levels by 2030, and (2) Microsoft's carbon negative initiatives lead to a measurable decrease in CO2 emissions in the tech sector by 2028?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, credible evidence demonstrates that (a) Microsoft's carbon negative pledge has led to a measurable reduction in global CO2 levels of at least 1% compared to levels recorded in 2020, as reported by authoritative sources, and (b) by December 31, 2028, there is clear and measurable evidence that Microsoft’s carbon negative initiatives have resulted in a quantifiable decrease in CO2 emissions across the tech sector of at least 10% from the baseline year of 2020. Both pieces of evidence must be supported by peer-reviewed research or official reports from reputable organizations that analyze the effectiveness of corporate carbon pledges on global emissions and the tech sector.

P.title: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, credible evidence demonstrates that Microsoft's carbon negative pledge has led to a measurable reduction in global CO2 levels. The reduction must be at least 1% of global CO2 emissions compared to levels recorded in 2020, as reported by authoritative sources such as the Global Carbon Project or the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). metadata.source_question: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?

Q.title: Will other major tech companies follow Microsoft's lead in committing to carbon negative pledges by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, at least three major technology companies (defined as companies with a market capitalization over $10 billion) publicly commit to carbon negative pledges. A carbon negative pledge means that the company commits to removing more carbon dioxide from the atmosphere than it emits, with specific targets and timelines outlined in their sustainability reports or official announcements. The commitments must be verifiable and publicly available, and they must include measurable goals for carbon removal. Companies must be recognized as major players in the tech industry, such as those listed in the Fortune 500 or similar reputable sources. The commitment must be confirmed by credible news reports from at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Temporary initiatives or commitments that do not have a long-term strategy or measurable impact will not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impacts global CO2 levels by 2030 (2) at least three major tech companies commit to carbon negative pledges by 2025?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, credible evidence demonstrates that Microsoft's carbon negative pledge has led to a measurable reduction in global CO2 levels of at least 1% compared to levels recorded in 2020, attributed directly to Microsoft's initiatives and supported by peer-reviewed research or official reports from reputable organizations. Additionally, it will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, at least three major technology companies (with a market capitalization over $10 billion) publicly commit to carbon negative pledges, with verifiable commitments and measurable goals for carbon removal, confirmed by credible news reports from at least two major news organizations.

P.title: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States Senate has passed legislation that significantly alters or establishes new nuclear safety standards. Significant legislation is defined as any bill that: 
- Introduces new safety regulations for nuclear power plants, including but not limited to operational, environmental, or safety protocols. 
- Amends existing laws such as the Atomic Energy Act or the Nuclear Waste Policy Act in a way that enhances safety standards. 
The legislation must be officially signed into law by the President of the United States. The resolution will rely on official congressional records and reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) for verification. If multiple bills are introduced, at least one must be passed and signed into law for the resolution to be Yes.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

Q.title: Will international nuclear safety standards influence US legislation by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States Congress passes legislation that incorporates international nuclear safety standards into its regulatory framework. The legislation must explicitly reference and implement these standards, which are defined by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and other recognized international bodies. The legislation must be signed into law by the President of the United States. In the absence of new legislation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) indicating a significant influence of international nuclear safety standards on existing or proposed legislation will also suffice for a Yes resolution. If the legislation is passed but does not effectively implement the standards, the question will resolve as No.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) The US Senate passes significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025, and (2) International nuclear safety standards influence US legislation by 2025?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met by December 31, 2025: (1) The United States Senate has passed significant legislation that alters or establishes new nuclear safety standards, defined as any bill that introduces new safety regulations for nuclear power plants or amends existing laws like the Atomic Energy Act or Nuclear Waste Policy Act in a way that enhances safety standards, and this legislation must be signed into law by the President of the United States. (2) The United States Congress has passed legislation that incorporates international nuclear safety standards into its regulatory framework, explicitly referencing and implementing these standards defined by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and other recognized international bodies, and this legislation must also be signed into law by the President of the United States. In the absence of new legislation for the second condition, credible reports from at least three major news organizations indicating significant influence of international nuclear safety standards on existing or proposed legislation will also suffice for a Yes resolution. If either condition is not met, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: Will the US House of Representatives pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the US House of Representatives has passed legislation that significantly alters nuclear safety standards. Significant alterations include, but are not limited to, changes to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's regulations, the introduction of new safety protocols, or amendments that increase safety requirements for nuclear power plants. The legislation must be officially signed into law by the President to count as passed. Legislation that merely proposes changes or is under consideration will not be sufficient for a Yes resolution. Reports from major news organizations (e.g., CNN, The Washington Post, NPR) confirming the passage of such legislation will be considered authoritative.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

P_and_Q.title: Will both the US Senate and the US House of Representatives pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?
P_and_Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, both the United States Senate and the US House of Representatives have passed legislation that significantly alters or establishes new nuclear safety standards. Significant legislation is defined as any bill that: 
- For the Senate: Introduces new safety regulations for nuclear power plants, including but not limited to operational, environmental, or safety protocols; or amends existing laws such as the Atomic Energy Act or the Nuclear Waste Policy Act in a way that enhances safety standards. The legislation must be officially signed into law by the President of the United States. 
- For the House: Includes significant alterations such as changes to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's regulations, the introduction of new safety protocols, or amendments that increase safety requirements for nuclear power plants. This legislation must also be officially signed into law by the President. The resolution will rely on official congressional records and reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, CNN, NPR) for verification. If multiple bills are introduced, at least one must be passed and signed into law by both chambers for the resolution to be Yes.

Q.title: Will the US government increase funding for nuclear safety research by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the US government officially announces an increase in funding for nuclear safety research compared to the funding levels established in the fiscal year 2024. The increase must be documented in an official budget proposal or appropriation bill passed by Congress. The funding increase must be at least 10% over the 2024 levels to qualify. This question resolves as No if there is no official announcement or if the funding remains the same or decreases.

(2) The US government has officially announced an increase in funding for nuclear safety research compared to the funding levels established in the fiscal year 2024, with the increase documented in an official budget proposal or appropriation bill passed by Congress, and the increase being at least 10% over the 2024 levels. Q.title: Will there be a major public safety incident related to nuclear facilities in the US before 2025?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, any of the following incidents occur at a nuclear facility in the United States:
- A significant release of radioactive material that poses a threat to public health or safety, as determined by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) or the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).
- An incident that results in a fatality or serious injury to workers or the public due to operational failures or accidents at a nuclear facility.
- A major security breach at a nuclear facility that leads to unauthorized access to nuclear materials or poses a credible threat to public safety.

The incidents must be reported and verified by the NRC, or acknowledged by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Minor incidents or operational issues that do not result in public harm or significant safety threats do not count towards this question's resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

P_and_Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: 
1. By December 31, 2025, the United States Senate has passed legislation that significantly alters or establishes new nuclear safety standards, defined as any bill that: 
   - Introduces new safety regulations for nuclear power plants, including but not limited to operational, environmental, or safety protocols.

The resolution will rely on official congressional records and reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) for verification. If multiple bills are introduced, at least one must be passed and signed into law for the resolution to be Yes.

2. Before January 1, 2025, there are no major public safety incidents related to nuclear facilities in the United States, defined as: 
   - A significant release of radioactive material that poses a threat to public health or safety, as determined by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) or the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). 
   - An incident that results in a fatality or serious injury to workers or the public due to operational failures or accidents at a nuclear facility. 
   - A major security breach at a nuclear facility that leads to unauthorized access to nuclear materials or poses a credible threat to public safety. 
   The incidents must be reported and verified by the NRC, or acknowledged by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Minor incidents or operational issues that do not result in public harm or significant safety threats do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q.title: Will there be a major public debate about nuclear safety standards in the US by 2024?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, there is a publicly accessible debate or forum involving key stakeholders (government officials, industry representatives, and public interest groups) specifically focused on nuclear safety standards in the United States. The debate must be covered by at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must address issues such as regulatory changes, safety protocols, or public health concerns related to nuclear energy. If the debate occurs in a private setting or is not widely reported, the question will resolve as No. Additionally, any discussions that are purely academic or not aimed at public policy changes will not count towards this resolution.

P.title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is clear evidence of a significant increase in global soccer viewership attributed to the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams. Specifically, this will be measured by: 1. An increase of at least 20% in the average global viewership numbers for the World Cup compared to the previous tournament with 32 teams in 2018. 2. Official reports from FIFA or credible third-party sources (such as Nielsen or similar audience measurement organizations) confirming this increase. 3. The increase must be directly linked to the expanded format, meaning that viewership figures must show a correlation with the expansion and not be influenced by other factors (e.g., the popularity of specific teams or players). In the absence of clear data from FIFA, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, etc.) will suffice to confirm the increase.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

Q.title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a higher number of participating countries in future tournaments by 2034?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2034, the FIFA World Cup, having expanded to 48 teams starting from the 2026 tournament, sees an increase in the number of participating countries in at least one subsequent tournament compared to the number of participating countries in the last tournament before the expansion (which had 32 teams). The increase must be recognized by FIFA and reported in official documentation. Additionally, if any tournament held after 2026 has more than 32 participating countries, this will satisfy the resolution criteria. The resolution will not count temporary or special invitations that are not part of the regular qualification process.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

Official reports from FIFA or credible third-party sources (such as Nielsen or similar audience measurement organizations) confirming this increase, directly linked to the expanded format. (2) By December 31, 2034, the FIFA World Cup, having expanded to 48 teams starting from the 2026 tournament, sees an increase in the number of participating countries in at least one subsequent tournament compared to the 32 teams in the last tournament before the expansion. This increase must be recognized by FIFA and reported in official documentation, excluding temporary or special invitations.

Q.title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams result in a notable increase in sponsorship revenue for FIFA by 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, FIFA reports a notable increase in sponsorship revenue directly attributed to the expansion of the FIFA World Cup to 48 teams. A 'notable increase' is defined as an increase of at least 20% in sponsorship revenue compared to the last World Cup held with 32 teams (2018). This increase must be confirmed in FIFA's official financial statements or through credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, or Reuters). The increase must be directly linked to the expansion and not influenced by other factors such as general market growth or other tournaments. In the event of ambiguity, the resolution will rely on FIFA's official communication regarding the impact of the expansion on sponsorship revenue.

Q.title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to the introduction of new soccer markets by 2032?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, at least two new soccer markets are officially recognized as having professional leagues or significant national representation in international soccer tournaments as a direct result of the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams. A 'new soccer market' is defined as a country or region that has not previously had a significant presence in international soccer competitions, specifically those that have not qualified for a World Cup or continental championship in the last 20 years. The recognition must come from FIFA or a reputable soccer governing body, and the new markets must demonstrate a sustainable soccer infrastructure, including a professional league and national team participation in FIFA-sanctioned tournaments. Reports from credible sources such as FIFA, BBC, The Guardian, or similar outlets will be accepted as evidence.

Q.title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams result in a higher average attendance at matches by 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the average attendance at matches during the FIFA World Cup, which will be held in 2026 with 48 teams, is higher than the average attendance recorded during the previous World Cup held in 2022. The average attendance will be calculated based on the total number of attendees across all matches divided by the number of matches played during the tournament. The attendance figures must be reported by FIFA and corroborated by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In case of any matches played without spectators or in empty stadiums, those matches will be excluded from the average attendance calculation.

Q.title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to an increase in the number of countries participating in the tournament by 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, at least 10 new countries that have never previously qualified for the FIFA World Cup participate in the tournament following the expansion to 48 teams. These countries must qualify through the official FIFA qualification process for the World Cup, and their participation must be confirmed by FIFA in the official tournament records. The expansion must be in effect for at least one tournament prior to this date, and the qualification must be for the 2026 or 2030 World Cup. Countries that have previously participated in World Cup tournaments do not count as new participants.
